etymologies: late 19th century. From French callose from classical Latin callus + French -ose

definitions: A polysaccharide found in higher plants as a constituent of certain types of cell wall, and deposited on parts of the plasma membrane in response to wounding or physiological stress.

notes.text: Callose is a linear polymer of glucose.

etymologies: late Middle English; earliest use found in Lanfranc's Science of Cirurgie. From classical Latin callōsus callous

definitions: Originally: (of animal tissue or skin) hardened, thickened; = "callous". In later use also Botany: bearing one or more callosities.
